questions.text: 85 yrs old ramu presented with nasal bleed;on examination person was too anaemic.Bleeding didn’t responded to anterior nasal packing.Most common site of bleed in such clinical situation would be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Woodruff’s plexus. In elderly patients with severe anemia and persistent nasal bleeding that does not respond to anterior nasal packing, the most common site of bleeding is Woodruff’s plexus, which is located in the posterior part of the lateral nasal wall. Posterior epistaxis is more common in older individuals and is often associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension and coagulopathies. Unlike anterior epistaxis, which is more common in younger individuals and typically arises from Kiesselbach’s plexus (Little’s area), posterior bleeding tends to be more severe and difficult to control because the vessels involved are larger and situated deeper within the nasal cavity. Bleeding from Woodruff’s plexus is often profuse, recurrent, and requires posterior nasal packing or more invasive interventions like arterial ligation or embolization. Incorrect Options: A. Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus) – Incorrect Little’s area is the most common site of anterior epistaxis, which is more frequent in young individuals and is usually caused by trauma, dry air, or local irritation. However, in elderly patients with persistent bleeding unresponsive to anterior packing, posterior epistaxis is more likely, making Woodruff’s plexus the correct answer. B. Retro-columellar region – Incorrect The retro-columellar region refers to the area just behind the columella, which is part of Little’s area. Since Little’s area is responsible for anterior epistaxis and the question describes a case resistant to anterior packing, this option is not the most appropriate. D. Both Little’s area and retro-columellar region – Incorrect Both of these regions are part of the anterior nasal septum and are commonly involved in anterior epistaxis. However, since the patient in question is elderly, severely anemic, and has bleeding unresponsive to anterior packing, the most likely source of bleeding is posterior (Woodruff’s plexus), ruling out this option.

questions.text: MC cause of epistaxis in 3 years old child :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trauma. Trauma is the most common cause of epistaxis in a 3-year-old child. Young children frequently engage in nose-picking (digital trauma), which can injure the fragile blood vessels of Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus), leading to anterior nasal bleeding. Additionally, children are prone to falls, bumps, or minor injuries during play, all of which can cause trauma-induced epistaxis. Since the nasal mucosa in young children is delicate and richly vascularized, even minor trauma can result in significant bleeding. Incorrect Options: A. Nasal polyp Nasal polyps are rare in young children and are more commonly associated with chronic inflammatory conditions like cystic fibrosis. They usually present with nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea rather than epistaxis. Therefore, nasal polyps are an unlikely cause of nosebleeds in a 3-year-old. B. Foreign body While foreign bodies are common in young children due to their tendency to insert objects into their noses, they typically cause unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge and sometimes recurrent localized infections. Although they may cause epistaxis if they erode the mucosa, they are not the most common cause of bleeding. C. Upper respiratory catarrh Upper respiratory infections (URIs) can cause nasal mucosal inflammation and congestion, leading to minor bleeding episodes. However, trauma remains the leading cause of epistaxis in young children, making this option less likely as the primary cause.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding epistaxis is untrue:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Woodruff’s plexus appears to originate from the posterior pharyngeal wall and is arterial in origin (Untrue Statement). Woodruff’s plexus is a network of veins located in the posterior part of the lateral nasal wall, and it is primarily venous in origin, not arterial. The incorrect part of the statement is the claim that it originates from the posterior pharyngeal wall and is arterial. Unlike Kiesselbach’s plexus, which is the main site for anterior epistaxis and is supplied by branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, Woodruff’s plexus is primarily involved in posterior epistaxis, which is often venous in nature. Incorrect Options: A. Anterior epistaxis is more common Anterior epistaxis accounts for 90% of nosebleeds, commonly originating from Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus). It is usually mild, self-limiting, and more common in children and young adults due to trauma (e.g., nose-picking) or dry air. C. In young persons, venous bleeding is more common In young individuals, epistaxis often results from minor trauma or mucosal irritation, leading to venous oozing rather than brisk arterial bleeding. Since the anterior nasal mucosa is highly vascularized, small venous bleeds are common in this age group. D. Posterior epistaxis usually occurs after 40 years Posterior epistaxis is more common in older adults (typically above 40 years) and is often associated with hypertension, atherosclerosis, or coagulopathies. It is usually more severe than anterior epistaxis and originates from branches of the sphenopalatine artery, requiring more intensive management, including posterior nasal packing or arterial embolization

questions.text: Kiesselbach’s Plexus (Little’s area) is contributed by all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Posterior ethmoidal artery. Explanation for the Correct Answer (B – Posterior Ethmoidal Artery is NOT a Contributor): Kiesselbach’s plexus (Little’s area) is a richly vascularized region on the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum and is the most common site of anterior epistaxis. It is formed by an anastomosis of five arteries, but the posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to this plexus. The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and primarily supplies the superior and posterior parts of the nasal septum, making it irrelevant to Kiesselbach’s plexus. Incorrect Options: A. Anterior Ethmoidal Artery The anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system), contributes to Kiesselbach’s plexus by supplying the anterior part of the nasal septum. C. Greater Palatine Artery The greater palatine artery, a branch of the maxillary artery (from the external carotid system), enters the nasal cavity through the incisive canal and helps supply Little’s area. D. Sphenopalatine Artery The sphenopalatine artery, the terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is the major contributor to nasal blood supply and has branches that anastomose in Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated in case of epistaxis control?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Internal carotid artery. The internal carotid artery (ICA) is not ligated in the management of epistaxis because it is a major artery supplying the brain, and ligating it could lead to severe complications like stroke or neurological deficits. While branches of the internal carotid artery (such as the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries) may be involved in epistaxis, direct ligation of the ICA itself is not an option. Instead, embolization of its branches may be performed if necessary. Incorrect Options: A. Anterior Ethmoidal Artery – Can Be Ligated The anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system), supplies the anterior and superior nasal septum. In cases of severe anterior epistaxis, this artery can be ligated via an external approach through the medial orbit. B. Maxillary Artery – Can Be Ligated The maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, is the main supplier of the posterior nasal cavity through its terminal branch, the sphenopalatine artery. It is frequently ligated in posterior epistaxis through an intraoral (transantral) or endoscopic approach. C. External Carotid Artery – Can Be Ligated The external carotid artery gives off the maxillary artery, which is a major contributor to nasal bleeding. In severe, intractable epistaxis, especially when other measures fail, the external carotid artery may be ligated to reduce blood flow to the nasal mucosa.
